awd_titl_txt: Environmental Computing and Community Engagement in Undergraduate STEM Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest in high quality undergraduate STEM education by introducing a computational, community-oriented component into STEM programs at Xavier University.  Specifically, undergraduate students will develop microcontroller-based systems for collecting airborne particulate data.  They will work with public school teachers and students to deploy the sensors at locations around New Orleans and to analyze the resulting data. Airborne particulates are often the pollutant of greatest concern in minority and other underserved communities. This project will provide undergraduates and the students they mentor with learning experiences that are relevant to the students and their communities.  Research has shown positive effects from student involvement in such real-world, personally relevant STEM projects, including increases in student interest in STEM-related careers after graduation. As a result, the project has the potential to broaden student interest in STEM and increase pursuit of STEM-related majors.

The project has two specific aims:  1) to develop microcontroller-based systems for collecting environmental data (primarily airborne particulates) and deploy the systems at locations around New Orleans; and (2) to engage Xavier undergraduates in working with public school teachers and students, and government agencies to apply STEM methods to address environmental problems.  The project will help to address insufficient spatiotemporal air quality sampling in and around Xavier University.  The project uses a tiered mentoring system in which the project team members mentor undergraduates, who in turn work with public school teachers and mentor their students.  Utilization-focused evaluation strategies will accommodate student and teacher feedback to ensure that project activities meet local interests and needs. The project will make use of internal and external program tracking and benchmarking metrics to measure student recruitment, retention, and persistence. Analysis and biannual reporting of quantitative and qualitative data collected via surveys, interviews, and student tracking will be used to assess project performance, inform project direction, and evaluate the effects of program elements on the performance, motivation, and aspirations of teachers and students. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

Award Title: Environmental Computing and Community Engagement in Undergraduate STEM Education
Federal Award ID: 2044192
Report Submission Period: 02/01/2024 to 01/31/2025

Project Overview

The Environmental Computing and Community Engagement in Undergraduate STEM Education (ECoSTEM) project aimed to integrate environmental data collection, computing, and community engagement into STEM education at Xavier University of Louisiana. By developing microcontroller-based systems for monitoring airborne particulate matter (PM2.5), the project fostered hands-on learning, broadened STEM participation, and increased environmental awareness in local communities.

Intellectual Merit

The ECoSTEM project developed innovative, low-cost air quality monitoring systems using Arduino microcontrollers. These systems were deployed throughout New Orleans, including at Xavier University and in the Lower Ninth Ward district of New Orleans. The data collected contributed to research on air quality trends, sensor performance, and environmental justice awereness. Undergraduate students gained experience in electronics, programming, and data analysis, preparing them for careers in STEM fields. The project also led to peer-reviewed publications and conference presentations that shared findings with the broader scientific community.

Broader Impacts

ECoSTEM engaged a diverse group of students, educators, and community members in STEM learning and environmental research. Highlights include:

  • Student Participation: 32 undergraduate students were hired over four years to conduct research, develop monitoring systems, and present findings at national conferences.
  • Teacher Training: Two week-long workshops trained 10 high school teachers on using microcontroller-based air quality monitors in their STEM curricula.
  • Community Engagement: Collaborated with the Sankofa Community Development Corporation and STEM-NOLA to deploy sensors and conduct workshops, reaching over 100 high school students.
  • Public Outreach: Project activities and data were made accessible via the ECoSTEM website, fostering transparency and public engagement in environmental monitoring efforts.

 

 

Key Findings and Achievements

  • Successfully developed and deployed a network of homemade and commercial PM2.5 sensors across New Orleans.
  • Validated sensor performance by comparing ECoSTEM systems with Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality monitors.
  • Improved STEM curriculum by integrating environmental monitoring projects into coursework.
  • Strengthened partnerships with local organizations to support continued community-based research and education.

Dissemination of Results

Findings were shared through various channels:

  • Website: The ECoSTEM website (https://instesre.org/ECoSTEM/index.html. ) hosts data, research updates, and project resources.
  • Conferences and Publications: Students and faculty presented research at conferences such as the AGU Fall Meeting, the HBCU Climate Change Conference, and the Environmental Justice Conference.
  • Community Engagement: Workshops and presentations reached local schools and community groups, promoting STEM education and environmental awareness.

Conclusion

The ECoSTEM project successfully combined environmental research, computing, and community engagement to enhance undergraduate STEM education. By providing students with hands-on research opportunities, training educators, and fostering partnerships with community organizations, the project has laid the foundation for future environmental monitoring initiatives in New Orleans and beyond. The knowledge and skills gained by students and teachers will continue to support STEM workforce development and public understanding of air quality issues.
